keyTakeAways: Peanut allergies in U.S. children have declined significantly since 2015, with a 27% drop after 2015 guidelines and over 40% drop after 2017 updates.
Approximately 60,000 children have avoided food allergies since 2015, including 40,000 who otherwise would have developed peanut allergies.
The LEAP trial (2015) showed that early introduction of peanuts reduces future food allergy risk by over 80%, with protection lasting into adolescence in about 70% of children.
Early allergen introduction is recommended between four and six months of age, without prior screening, according to updated 2021 guidelines.
Only about 29% of pediatricians and 65% of allergists initially followed the expanded 2017 guidance due to confusion and concerns about implementation outside clinical settings.
The study analyzed electronic health records from pediatric practices and supports the real-world adoption of early allergen exposure practices.
Advocacy groups such as FARE support the shift to early introduction, emphasizing it as a key strategy to reduce the prevalence of peanut allergies nationwide.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A decade after the LEAP trial demonstrated that early exposure to peanuts in infancy can prevent peanut allergies, new research shows a significant decline in allergy rates in the U.S. Since 2015, when guidelines recommended introducing peanuts to infants as early as four months, peanut allergy rates in children under age three have dropped by more than 27%, and by over 40% after expanded recommendations in 2017. A study by Dr. David Hill at Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia, analyzing electronic health records, found that around 40,000 children who would have otherwise developed peanut allergies have avoided them. The LEAP trial, led by Gideon Lack at King’s College London, showed early allergen exposure reduces allergy risk by over 80%. Despite initial hesitancy among medical professionals—only about 29% of pediatricians followed the guidelines—adoption has grown, supported by advocacy from groups like FARE. Experts now recommend introducing allergens such as peanut butter, milk-based yogurt, and soy-based products between four and six months of age, with little or no prior screening. The findings highlight a measurable public health success in reducing the prevalence of life-threatening food allergies.
title: Early Peanut Introduction in Infants Reduces Allergy Rates in U.S. Children
